@pagles  "it can be a replacement for pypi" -- jezdez (irc) :-)

I'm trying to clear up what PyPI is and what it's capable of. I've just done a major rewrite of the home page in an attempt to communicate more clearly the facilities it provides (which have nothing to do with ratings).

@r1chardj0n3s The quote "it can be a replacement for pypi" is taken out of context really, Depot isn't a replacement for PyPI per se, in fact Depot will complement it pretty nicely and will require a canonical source for packages in case the Depot users want to track public releases.

At Depot we are long time users of PyPI -- and in my case contributors to the community efforts (such as being a server admin of PyPI, co-author of pip and virtualenv, etc). But in that capacity we strongly believe that there are complex deployment scenarios that require more than just an Apache DirectoryIndex page.

@jezdez so are you saying that a public repot on Depot can not be the canonical  source for that package?  If it can be, and other things like Depot spring up, what does that mean for fragmentation of canonical index space for something like pip?
@jezdez thanks for clarifying!

@ptone PyPI is by design the canonical (read: default) source for packages if you use the defacto standard installation tools easy_install, pip, buildout. Each of those tools provide hooks to change or extend the list of indexes to install from. Just as other products (PyPM index, Plone's Software Center, Chishop, z3c.pypimirror, etc) Depot will use this capability one way or another, too. I'm not sure what you mean with "fragmentation of canonical index space" -- to me PyPI is the canonical index for Open Source software, gratuitously hosted by the Python Software Foundation (and its mirror providers). In other words, it's a reasonable default for public software, but sometimes not enough as a project hosting solution.
Python's non-pypi hosted packages should be done like rubygems

"Your files are saved on proven file storage systems and served securely over SSL via our robust infrastructure. Never worry about PyPI downtimes again." Why exactly should I believe depot.io will have better uptime than pypi?  If it was a turn-key solution for making my own pypi index I could host, I might be interested
@chadselph Does chishop not address that?
@jezdez I think that you might have meant "graciously hosted" ... or maybe not? :-)

@chadselph Well, Depot will receive the highest of maintenance support we can imagine, including 24/7 monitoring, off-site backups and fault-tolerant deployment. In other words, we do things that I *know* PyPI doesn't do or have. If you want to host one of your depots inside your firewall, you'll be glad to hear that we have a turn-key solution planned for the future, too.
@r1chardj0n3s Yeah, my fault, damn you native speakers :)

@jezdez by fragmentation, I mean that if depot.io or similar adds enough value for open source that a project doesn't bother pushing to PyPI, then the installer tools don't have a single index to search.

@ptone Ah, I can only speculate here since I haven't used alternative indexes to release my open source software before, but it would probably come with a toll of fragmentation, indeed. OTOH, the Plone Software Center is a good example how this could work for a community specific index.
@jezdez Plone Software Center is disliked by the Plone community. They can't wait for Plone Packages. ;)
